content.description: A splitter going from thin hands to cupped hands then back to off-hands.  Shares the anchor with Terminator, Left.  Clip the tat and lower off.
content.location: There is a walk-on ledge on the left side of the East Pillar that is used to access Ray’s Pin Job, Something for Nothing and Terminator Left/Right.

content.description: A short but splitter off-fingers crack.  The crux comes about 20’ up when you have to do a crack switch.  At the top move right to a manky anchor and lower back to the ground.  Can be a little wet in the spring.
content.protection: Single from fingers to hands with double .4 and .5
content.location: There is a walk-on ledge on the left side of the East Pillar that is used to access Ray’s Pin Job, Something for Nothing and Terminator Left/Right.

content.description: The obvious thin corner to the right of Ray’s Pin Job.  The PG-13 rating is for the pile of stacked blocks at the beginning of the corner.  They are probably unstable.  All that aside the corner looks appealing and could be nice if it got cleaned up.  To get off rappel back to the walk-on ledge.

This is the furthest route on the left.  Begin on a good ledge with a 20 foot stretch of wide hands to a ledge and then comes the business, 60’ of thin fingertip laybacking and stemming on lichen.  It is best to break it up into two short pitches.  There is a fixed anchor with tat to rappel back to the starting ledge.
content.location: There is a walk-on ledge on the left side of the East Pillar that is used to access Ray’s Pin Job, Something for Nothing and Terminator Left/Right.

content.description:
The obvious, gorgeous, coveted headwall splitter at the Cookie.

Classic!

A difficult 12+ slab move as New Leaf breaks from Greenleaf brings you to the 5' roof and the crux establishing yourself on the headwall.

Sustained 12+ to the summit.
content.location:
Climb the 1st p. of The Greenleaf (12b).

Climb most of the 2nd p. (12c), and follow the crack up the headwall instead of escaping right to the Greenleaf 2nd p. anchor.

climbs.name: Legends of the Low Sierra
climbs.fa: Brian Ketron, Nathan Kerr and Ryan Kelly, 2013

content.description: One of the best at the cliff!  This beautiful sport climb includes everything from slab to desperate compression.  There is 10 protection bolts and a 2 bolt anchor with chains.  The crux comes around bolts 8 and 9, where you have to make a series of very insecure moves.
content.protection: Bolts, optional off-finger sized piece after the third bolt
content.location: This is the second route from the right

climbs.name: Legends Light
climbs.fa: 2013, Brian Ketron, Jesse McGahey, Sean Jones

content.description: A great warm-up if trying some of the harder stuff in the area.  The route consists of a balancey areté for right hand and and perfect flat crimps for your left.  There are 10 lead and bolts and 2 anchor bolts with rap-chains.
content.location: The furthest route on the right,  it shares the start with Legends of the Low Sierra.

content.description: The extension to Iced Earth. Sean Leary's original vision was an extension to Something For Nothing. He tried a few times to lead this mega-pitch from the ground, but rope drag made doing the final moves nearly impossible. So Sean bolted the extension to Iced Earth to the same finishing moves. Sean passed away B4 he sent. I'm happy that the FA went to such a kind person. I'm sure Stanley would be as well.
content.protection: 15 bolts? and a couple pieces to 2"
content.location: Climb Iced Earth, and continue for a few more bolts.

content.description:
3 bolts of easier climbing lead to the arete.

Climb the left side with some very technical 12b around the 5th bolt.

From here reachy moves get you up to the traverse. Big reaches left lead to a semi rest before the powerful crux bulge. Relatively easier to the anchor.
content.protection: Bolts with a couple of pieces at the end. .75" range
content.location: The left most bolted route. Goes up and left.

content.description: This route sits high on the left side of the East Pillar.  You will need to do Something for Nothing, 5.11d as an approach pitch.  Once at the base move right onto the face and follow a thin crack to the summit.  Rappel the route.
content.protection: Thin to 3”, bring extra thin to fingers
content.location: There is a walk-on ledge on the left side of the East Pillar that is used to access Ray’s Pin Job, Something for Nothing and Terminator Left/Right.

climbs.name: The Greenleaf p. 2
climbs.fa: Brian Ketron, Ryan Kelly, Jesse Mcgahee

content.description:
This is the 2nd pitch of The Greenleaf.

Fun climbing leads you up 20' until you start underclinging right.

Place high pro, and pull some difficult moves pinching the blunt arete. Set up and throw a foot out right to get established back in the crack.

Sustained 12a crack moves eventually get you to the roof.

Clip a bolt up and right, and move over right to the anchor.
content.location: From the anchor at the top of the 1st pitch, head up the obvious beautiful crack/flake splitting the headwall

climbs.name: The Greenleaf p. 1
climbs.fa: Brian Ketron, Sean Leary, Ryan Kelly

content.description:
Head up the first 3. Bolts of Iced Earth, continue up the easy 4" crack in the dihedral.

Then bolts lead out left to the arete. Work up the arete, steep moves with big reaches. Eventually get to a right leg kneebar for a rest before the Crux, which involves steep jamming. Easier to the anchor
content.location: Start on the furthest left line of bolts. Go straight up where Iced goes left.
